Trying to take inspiration from his ever changing generation, Karel's poetry radiates the personality, attitudes, and energy of today's youth. When he's not out making his audience smile with his poetry, Karel is an avid music listener, tv show binger, and breakfast eater. If he's not bringing joy to others in his performance, you can be sure Karel is out somewhere making somebody's day, awesome.Brian Lanigan is 19 years old and reads poetry to anyone who will listen in Toronto, Ontario. Though new to the poetry scene, Brian has already performed at numerous competitions across the GTA as both a competitor and featured artist (alongside the BTdot team). Brian has led poetry workshops at his high school and enjoys showing his peers that anyone make a living out of doing what they love. He also hopes to use poetry to reach out to those in need of a creative outlet. Both Brian's passion for poetry and drive to succeed make him someone to rememberThe BreakdownThe $1500 that we hope to raise will go towards:- Event Registration Fees (Fun fact: Brave New Voices, the largest youth slam festival in the world, has a $1250 team registration fee alone!)- Transportation- Lodging- Food, supplies, etc. Funds collected will be divided up towards the fees (registration, lodging, travel, etc.) of the following spoken word events and festivals:- SLAMtario: July 11th-12th(Toronto)- Brave New Voices: July 16th-20th- Canadian Festival of Spoken Word YouthCanSlam: August 20-25 (Ottawa)- And more to be announced!The ImpactSpoken word poetry is an artform that almost anybody can do and is accessible to everyone. You don't even need a pen and paper. All you need are your thoughts. Spoken word poetry can cover any issue: race, violence, immigration, you name it. Your voice is the most powerful tool that you can ever use. As poets, we want to show youth that you can use poetry to save yourselves from the problems that you have on a daily basis. Spoken word poetry saves lives, and some of our poets are living examples of that. By supporting us, you're helping us show the world our voices. You're supporting a cause that is trying to change lives for the better and maybe even save a life. We are trying to raise awareness on topics that we feel aren't getting enough attention, as well as telling our stories and the stories of people who have inspired us and moved us in so many ways. Other Ways You Can Help- Follow us on twitter! twitter.com/BTdot for future updates!- Spread the word! Word of mouth is the best way to raise awareness! - Check us out on Youtube! Youtube.com/user/SpokenWard ! Like, comment, share, subscribe! Any help will be greatly appreciated!- Share this page! We can use all the help we can get! SUPPORT THE B.TDOT / BAM! TORONTO YOUTH POETRY SLAM TEAM OF 2013-2014!

story:
Help us bring a day full of contemporary Iranian arts and music to the city of Calgary's beautiful Olympic Plaza on July 26, 2014.  Together, we will create an unforgettable experience and inspire our children by fostering cross-cultural dialogue and intercultural exchange. Tabestoon will be featuring live stage performances by London-based alternative rock band, Ali Azimi, Iranian fusion band, Ajam and numerous live performances by local and independent musicians and dancers. We will explore Iranian handicrafts, calligraphy, and have a Persian carpet-weaving workshop. Artworks by contemporary Iranian artists and a photo exhibit by German photographer Benedikt Fuhrmann will be showcased.


    Your Contribution

    Tabestoon is organized by the Persian Gulf Foundation, a registered, Canadian, non-profit organization dedicated to promoting Iranian arts and culture.  We are a team of volunteers who have been working tirelessly for months to bring a full day of Tabestoon to Calgary. We need $10,000 to cover the costs of our high quality programming; renting facilities and equipment, bringing international artists, and producing a live coverage of the event for Iranian art lovers across the globe.  Your contributions will help us put Calgary and Canada on the map for Iranian artists and intellectuals.

    Please help us make a lasting impact on the Canadian cultural scene and inspire the next generation of Iranian-Canadians.

    Thank You!

    Team Tabestoon

story:
Short Summary

Yuya Negishi, beloved painter of the Minneapolis/Saint Paul art community, recently suffered a tragic loss when thieves broke into his vehicle and stole many of his tools. This crowdfunding project is an effort to help Yuya recover and continue practicing his trade.

Much of Yuya's art can be seen at his Facebook and Pintrest pages:
https://www.facebook.com/yuya.negishi.7/photos
http://www.pinterest.com/yuyart/


What We Need & What You Get

This project seeks to raise $1000 to help Yuya acquire new equipment. Aside from the 4% fee that Indiegogo takes, every dollar will go to Yuya to help him out. Even if we don't meet our goal, that's okay. Every little bit helps. And of course if we exceed our goal, all the better! ^_^

Anyone who has seen Yuya's art on display at local galleries (or perhaps has even bought some) knows his talent and his skill. For someone like this to be targeted by common thieves is truly a tragedy, and one that our community can respond to by showing our support.

For the especially generous souls in our community (donations of $100+), Yuya will do a custom painting of approximately 12" by 12" in size. And if you are capable of even more ($200+ or $400+), Yuya will certainly be happy to create a larger work of art for you.


The Impact

Minneapolis and Saint Paul have one of the largest combined art communities in the nation, with artists and venues spanning every genre one can think of (and probably a few of the unthinkable sort). Everyone knows that artists are not in it for the cash; they practice their trade to share their passion with us. When artists are victimized in situations like this, many of them don't have the resources to simply "bounce back" from the loss. Your donation (any amount you can possibly afford) will be a tremendous aid to a wonderful member of the Twin Cities art community who moved here all the way from Japan to become one of us.


Other Ways You Can Help

For everyone who sees this site but if unable to donate right now, we would greatly appreciate it if you could share a link to here on any social media site you are active, such as Facebook, Twitter, etc. Thank you most kindly!   誠に有り難うございます！

story: Ladies and gentlemen, I am more than ecstatic to announce that RAW Artists have asked me to be apart of their incredible Art Showcase for a SECOND time, this coming February. With that said I am asking for contributions for what I have planned for this particular show. I am asking to raise around 500$ for the fees, details and the expenses to create large prints for the installation Art Work. I have so many incredible ideas, & have been working hard to create new artworks, and cannot wait for you to see the finished product. And any kind of contribution or help and support would be the icing on the cake! I have had so much positive feedback, and recognition for my work, and cannot thank anyone enough who has ever supported me- and through this you can be apart of the process and the ridiculous adventure to help me achieve my goal to becoming the Artist I wish to be! xoxo

story:
The members of FLAG STOP “welcome!” you to our fundraising page!

 

We are committed to supporting the arts and creating new opportunities in unique and unconventional places.  Our “background info" (below) will tell you all the facts about our project but don’t let that dry talk fool you—we are a group of art-centric people that have as much to do with the business of art, as we do with all things . . . “contemporary!”

 

This project will happen no matter what.  We have secured South Bay Lexus as our event hosts.  We have our “Curator Prospectus” and “Call for Artists” available on our website: www.FlagStopArt.com.  “Indiegogo” is a fundraising platform that will allow us to make this event bigger and better, for the talents we will be featuring.

 

Our efforts are broken into phases.  Phase 1, will allow us to purchase large containers to be installed on the grounds of Lexus.  We are hoping to afford 50 containers, as the more containers we have, the more curators and artists we can feature.  The more containers we can afford through fundraising, the higher are your chances of getting in!

 

Sit back, relax, and have a look at our video (there will be a quiz.)  After we get you all excited about helping us make “FLAG STOP” the most exciting art event of the century, keep updated on our blog “FlagStopArt.wordpress.com” and “Like” us on Facebook “Flag Stop 2011”. . . and get that submission in by July 15th!



--Background Information--

 

FLAG STOP

an alternative contemporary art event

 

Torrance, CA –  FLAG STOP is pleased to announce An Alternative Contemporary Art Event which presents art in unique, unconventional places. The goal of FLAG STOP is to give local art communities and the art world at large a chance to see and experience art where previously not thought possible. Torrance is a community where many local contemporary artists live and work, but is not currently known as an arts destination. FLAG STOP is creating the opportunity for curators, established artists, emerging artists, and local businesses to rethink the possibilities of exhibiting art within the context of a local community. South Bay Lexus in Torrance will be the first stop to present this unique art experience. The event will be held on September 2, 3, & 4, 2011 and is free and open to the public.

 

Mission:

FLAG STOP’s mission is to present new and emerging contemporary art to a larger audience outside the main stream art venues. FLAG STOP is searching for alternative venues in which to present the best curated examples of what, why, and how art is becoming relevant today. Each “STOP” will feature art which has been curated with some of the best examples of contemporary art, brought to you by some of the top professional, emerging curators and artists from Southern California.

 

About FLAG STOP:

FLAG STOP’s committee is a group of South Bay art supporters, promoters, artists, designers, curators, collectors, local businesses and art enthusiasts, working to establish a new destination opportunity to experience local and international contemporary art. FLAG STOP is creating the opportunity for communities to rethink the possibilities of exhibiting art.

 

www.FlagStopArt.com          www.FlagStopArt.wordpress.com

 

”Like” and follow us on Facebook: FLAG STOP 2011

story:
Our Story

One of the longest-standing community traditions in the country, the Annual Festival of Philippine Arts and Culture (FPAC) is a celebration of arts, music, dance, rituals, food, and yes, even giant vegetables.  More than this, FPAC is about: A FILIPINO VOICE, IDENTITY, COMMUNITY, HOME, YOUTH, FAMILY, TRADITION, LEADERSHIP, HEALING, EMPOWERMENT, A COMMON GROUND FOR DIVERSITY.  This year, FPAC will be held on September 8 - 9, 2012 at Pt. Fermin Park, San Pedro, Los Angeles.  

Our Impact

Started by the City of L.A., the Annual Festival of Philippine Arts & Culture (FPAC) has since evolved into a non-profit but has remained true to its community development vision, and over the past 20 years:

  • Increased the visibility of the Filipino American community in presenting over 7,000 artists, from traditional to contemporary,
  • Increased civic engagement for over 6,000 volunteers, involved over 100 organizations, and provided leadership training for over 80 youth leaders;
  • Provided a safe place for youth to learn about their culture in a community environment with over 1,500 inner-city youth engaged in Eskuwela Kultura education programs;
  • Rekindled social and cultural vibrancy among at least 5,000 elders and seniors as they pass on their wisdom and experience;
  • Stimulated the economy by connecting about 1,000 businesses to new audiences;
  • Promoted cultural tourism in LA, having reached over a quarter of a million people from all over the country.


Why do we need your help?

FPAC is at the center of the fabric of the community, and we need seed money to establish an Annual Fund to keep this program going. We are appealing to individuals like yourself who value arts, culture, family, and community -- to preserve this legacy for the next generations. 

Migration and increasing populations has led to a growing demand for arts programs that increase cultural integration, civic engagement, as well as economic vitality.  But with the current City of LA budget crisis, we need help to defray the increasing costs from formerly free public services provided by the Fire Dept, Police, and Bureau of Sanitation.

As community members, your participation is essential. Please support our arts, culture and our community by making a tax-deductible donation. Some may be able to give more and some less, we fully appreciate any amount you give.

For more information: log onto www.filamarts.org or call (213)380-FPAC.

Maraming salamat po at Mabuhay!

Increased civic engagement for over 6,000 volunteers, involved over 100 organizations, and provided leadership training for over 80 youth leaders;
Provided a safe place for youth to learn about their culture in a community environment with over 1,500 inner-city youth engaged in Eskuwela Kultura education programs;
Rekindled social and cultural vibrancy among at least 5,000 elders and seniors as they pass on their wisdom and experience;
Stimulated the economy by connecting about 1,000 businesses to new audiences;
Promoted cultural tourism in LA, having reached over a quarter of a million people from all over the country.

Why do we need your help?
FPAC is at the center of the fabric of the community, and we need seed money to establish an Annual Fund to keep this program going. We are appealing to individuals like yourself who value arts, culture, family, and community -- to preserve this legacy for the next generations. 
Migration and increasing populations has led to a growing demand for arts programs that increase cultural integration, civic engagement, as well as economic vitality.  But with the current City of LA budget crisis, we need help to defray the increasing costs from formerly free public services provided by the Fire Dept, Police, and Bureau of Sanitation.
As community members, your participation is essential. Please support our arts, culture and our community by making a tax-deductible donation. Some may be able to give more and some less, we fully appreciate any amount you give.
For more information: log onto www.filamarts.org or call (213)380-FPAC.
Maraming salamat po at Mabuhay!

story:
*UPDATE: Nov. 11th - A huge thank you to Phil Straus and Margaret Harris of Philadelphia for their generous donation by mail of $1000! As requested, here is the address where mail donations can be sent.  Please make checks payable to: ArtStart  and indicate that your contribution is for the Cambodian-American Teen Mural Project.

Mail to:  

ArtStart
716 Bennett Valley Road
Santa Rosa, CA 95404 

WHO WE ARE:

“We are Cambodian-American young women who live in Santa Rosa, CA.  We are apprentices at ArtStart, and with the help of another American apprentice, we are creating a mural to tell the story of our families and of Cambodia, a place of great beauty, ancient culture and also of genocide. It took us years to fully understand what our parents went through, and we were shocked.  Our history is not well known in the US, so we are telling our story through this memorial.  We seek to honor our parents and also those who died in the genocide.  We hope that people will learn—so please help us make that happen!” – Amy, Mathilda, and Vichaka 

WHY WE ARE HERE:

Meet Amy, Mathilda, and Vichaka.  These “Khmerican” young women have started a memorial project with significant goals:

  • To complete a 8'x16' mural that shows Cambodia’s rich history while honoring their parents and other survivors, as well as those who died in the 1975-1979 genocide of the Khmer Rouge under Pol Pot
  • To complete the artist apprenticeship at ArtStart in Santa Rosa
  • To hold a dedication ceremony on November 18th,  where the mural will be unveiled to the public for the first time
  • To travel with the mural to schools and libraries - spreading awareness in communities about Cambodia's culture and genocide.  This will facilitate the education other “Khmerican” kids as well as their American high school peers, and the American public at large

Through the apprenticeship at ArtStart, a local non-profit that mentors promising minority youth artists, these young women have been working on this amazing mural.   Funds from this campaign will be directly used to pay for:

  • All supplies used in the mural's creation
  • The artists' apprenticeship at ArtStart
  • The memorial dedication ceremony to be held on November 18th in Santa Rosa: including a blessing, traditional Khmer dancing, music, and Khmerican poetry
  • And, if we exceed our goal, all additional funds will help pay for Amy, Mathilda, and Vichaka to travel with the mural 

WE WANT YOU TO KNOW:

In contributing to this project, not only will you be funding a public work of art, you will also be giving three young women artists a valuable apprenticeship.  And most importantly, you will be furthering awareness of a significant human rights piece of our history.  You will be making this happen.  Our campaign "perks" will incorporate the art of the final mural as well as other artworks of Amy, Mathilda, and Vichaka.

ArtStart is a 501(c)3 non-profit, and your contributions will be tax-deductible less the cost of the perks. You will receive an email with the final information at the end of this campaign.

DISCOVER CAMBODIA'S RICH CULTURE: UNESCO / BEAUTY & DARKNESS

LEARN ABOUT THE KHMER ROUGE GENOCIDE

READ SURVIVOR STORIES

FIND OUT MORE ABOUT ARTSTART

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

Are you inspired by the project, but don’t have the funds to help?  One of the biggest things you can do for this project is to spread the word amongst others like you, who are passionate about art and human rights.  Above you will see links where you can share via Facebook, Twitter, Google + and good old fashioned email.  You can also leave us a comment.  Your word-of-mouth makes a difference and we thank you!

Cambodian-American Teen Mural Project Team:

Amy, Vichaka, and Mathilda – Cambodian-American young women artists
Chandra Woodworth – Artistic Director (ArtStart)
Natalie Berlucci - Senior Artist Mentor (ArtStart)
Mario Uribe - Co-Founder of ArtStart
Lucia Roncalli M.D. – Project Manager
Holly Allen – Mentor and Logistics
Heike van Nellen – Volunteer Coordinator
Lauren Smith – Campaign Technical Director 

CHECK OUT THE PROGRESS...LET'S MAKE THIS BIG.

story:
Send ToonSeum Executive Director Joe Wos to the International Cartoon Arts Museum Conference!

Over the past five year Joe has been the founder and volunteer director of the ToonSeum, Pittsburgh's Museum of Comic and Cartoon Art. This year he has been invited to become the first US Cartoon Art Museum representative to attend the international cartoon art museums conference in Kruishoutem, Belgium. Museums from throughout Europe and the Middle East will be attending. This is the 4th annual conference and is strictly limited to 30 attendees.

As you can imagine this is quite an honor and we are almost there! A generous board member of the ToonSeum has donated the airfare to and from Europe, and the conference itself covers some of the lodging cost.


But as you can imagine traveling to Europe is not cheap, additional lodging, trains, and other costs have to be factored in to make this happen.

The ToonSeum has grown substantially over the past five years, but we also know we have a long way to go. In Europe cartoon art museums are both widely respected and prevelant. We know there is much we can all learn from attending this conference.


Joe will arrive in Paris and then take a train to Belgium. This is his first visit to Europe and will be reaching out to cartoon art museums during his visit to establish exhibition sharing programs and much more.


We know not everyone can lend financial support. But there are other ways you can help. Joe welcomes travel advice, hotel vouchers, any way you can help.

This is a rare opportunity to take the ToonSeum to the international stage!

We thank you for your continued support of the Cartoon Arts!

story:
Kite Dream is my story simply told. 


Kite Dream is an artist's graphic novel about my life through dystonia, tainted blood, the joy and challenges of unexpected parenting and redemption through art and the love of art.

WHAT WILL THIS MONEY DO? The funds for the Kite Dream indiegogo project will help to  support me while I work on the graphic novel as well as contributing to the cost of materials. At the end of a year I will have the finished product . Your contribution will help Kite Dream to fly and to support the power of art.

I bring my 33 years of work as a full time artist to Kite Dream. Colour, shape humour and the use of symbols and dream come together in this project and it feels like a perfect fit to share my story and art with all of you. 

WHAT IS DYSTONIA?

Dystonia is a neurological disorder centered in the basal ganglia at the base of the brain.  Three clusters of neurons send out neurotransmitters (chemicals that direct movement.) With dystonia the wrong type or wrong amount of neurotransmitters are released causing a range of involuntary movement. The type of dystonia I have affects the head neck and shoulders with a range of involuntary movements and tremors. Dystonia comes with pain and dicomfort due to contortion of various parts of the body. My current treatment is injections of botulism toxins every three months (one of the best treatments available.) A side effect of this treatment is  the thickening of  certain muscles and a distortion of the appearance of muscles around the injection sites.

Cats & Cocktails

This is phase 1 of a 2 year art project.  Your support will make this project possible.   

  • Phase 1 is creating Kite Dream, the artist's graphic novel .
  • Phase 2 will be the actual printing or  publishing of the book .
You could appear in the book, get an unique commission of your cat in Riley style, enjoy cocktails with the artist, proudly sport a Kite Dream T-shirt or enjoy art year-round, My sincere thanks goes out to all supporters, whatever the contribution amount. 

This story begins in 1991 when I awoke...

One  fall morning with dystonia, a  disease I had not heard of but would come to know well.  My Lesbian community surrounded me during these years as they do today.

Kite Dream also describes my sister's nine year journey to death in 2000, a victim of the Canadian Tainted Blood Scandal. 

I became an unexpected parent to my sister's beloved daughter  Victoria and experienced the joys and challenges of unexpected parenting.

Interwoven and pulling together all the threads of my life are the artworks I have completed over the past two decades. (at the time that dystonia  made an appearance,I had already spent a decade dedicated to  art )


Join the Riley Community

Everyone can contribute.

  • Share
  • Celebrate
  • Love 
  • Life

And that's all there is to it.

Thank-you!

story: For those of you who do not know, my wife works for the Humane Society of Charlotte. She is doing great work for an awesome organization but her job involves having to bring work home. There is a lot to be done to make sure the puppies and kitties get all the help they need. She puts in a lot of long hours and I want to give her a nice home office where she can be comfortable and get work done away from the distractions of the furry yet cute work she also tends to bring home. Due to some recent financial set backs, I do not have the money alone to make this happen and would love to surprise her as she works very hard and deserves it. She does a lot to help others and I want to give something back to her. Unfortunately, this campaign will not have any perks for those who choose to donate but think of all the cute animals that will benefit for the extra time she can put in at the house. I know this is a long shot but I am asking for some help. If everyone gives just a little I can reach my goal and surprise her with a great gift for the sacrifices she has made since accepting this position.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Dave. I own a very small machine shop in Tarrytown, NY.  I am planning to expand the shop and retool to make beautiful replica engines. The focus is not only to provide functioning engines, but also something that would look good on display. These will not only be functioning engines, but also something that would look good on display. We will also be developing our own unique designs.  All machines and parts are hand made, meaning very little CNC work here. There is some recycling done in the process as well. Some parts may be recast from scrap and re-machined. This is not something that will be mass-produced. You will know that every engine we make will have the attention it deserves.

Here are some examples of the engines that we will be building:

The Atkinson-Cycle Engine:

Photo courtesy Wikipedia

And the Essex Hot air engine:

Photo courtesy myfordboy.blogspot.com

The goal is to supplement the existing shop as well as update some of the dated equipment:
  • The current lathes are too small. We'll have to get one that can handle larger flywheels and parts.
  • The vertical milling machine we have was made in 1942 and is quite worn out. We'll need an up to date milling machine with tighter tolerances as well as compatible tooling and accessories.
  • A large ring roller is needed to make flywheels.
  • Higher capacity bandsaws. We currently have a cheap 4" horizontal bandsaw. It is not very good at cutting, well... anything, really. We hate it.
  • Master patterns, and casts will have to be made for each design.

If the funding goal is reached, the shop should have everything it needs to start producing. Every little bit helps and if the funding comes up short, it would be unfortunate, and delay getting set up, but we would like the project to still move forward. 


The Perks

We want you to feel good about contributing to our project and would like to show our appreciation. We're putting together some things that we can offer you:

  • A few bucks will get our thanks and your name as a contributor on our website.
  • T-shirts with our logo will be offered.
  • higher contributors can receive a stainless steel pendant commemorating our project.
  • major contributors will have the opportunity to have a design named after them; Imagine the "<your name here> engine"!

Other Ways You Can Help

Obviously, donating to the cause will help a great deal...this is a huge project and we need lots of support. If we reach our goal, the costs are less than if we don't... so that offers some incentive to letting people know about the project. Donating AND enthusiastically spreading the word about it is the best of both worlds.  We understand some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help! The more people who visit and promote our campaign, the greater the chance we will be a featured project at a later date.  So, share with your facebook, twitter, instagram, linkedin, and other friends. 

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

And know that we are grateful for your participation in whatever way you can. We will work hard to make you proud that you contributed to our campaign!

story:
Who I Am and What I'm Doing!

My name is Michael Kline and I am a potter living in the mountains of North Carolina. I have been a full time potter for over 20 years. During that time I have fired a large wood burning kiln almost exclusively. For the past year I have been experimenting with a new body of work, fired in a soda kiln. This firing process has allowed me to evolve and expand my finishing and glazing techniques in exciting directions. Having hauled pots around to rented kilns for the past year, it is time for me to commit to my own kiln to work toward my potential with this process. As an artist it's important to dive deeply into one's work and explore new ways to express one's creativity. I invite you to be a part of expanding my creative horizon line.

As a potter, the kiln is a critical tool, and an enormous investment and commitment. The wood kiln I built in 2002 has served me well, and will still be fired several times a year. I have been working with master kiln builder, William Baker, to design the new propane fired soda kiln. The kiln will be smaller in scale than my wood kiln, and will be less labor intensive to fire. The smaller size will allow for a shorter turnaround as I experiment with surfaces and glazes. The new pots are time and labor intensive to make, so the scale of the kiln is important. I hired William for his design expertise as well as his meticulous attention to detail and skill as a builder. I will work alongside him to build the kiln, and I couldn't be more excited.

The soda kiln is the next great step for me as an artist. It will allow me to continue the momentum I have been building with this new body of work, and take it in new directions. Building a new kiln is a huge undertaking in every sense, and I thank you for helping me to achieve this dream.


What We Need

Building the kiln will require an upfront investment of $21,000

What's been done:

  • Kiln Shelves have been purchased
  • A kiln shed is built  
  • A concrete slab is ready to be poured
What's still needed :
  • Propane tank install
  • Gas lines trenched, installed, and connected
  • Purchase and shipment of super duty high temperature refractories
  • Steel work, including welding kiln bracing, chimney, damper, lentil, burner stands
  • 4 B5 burners with 90 head 2.1 mil/BTU High Pressure LP
  • Concrete block and other  construction materials

What You Get

Along with the community of passionate supporters that you will be part of there are a few very nice perks for your generosity! Words can't always express my appreciation but sometimes pottery can! See descriptions for details. There are various times that I will be able to fulfill them, so please make a note of delivery schedules if you are thinking of sending some of these as gifts. Christmas is just around the corner! ;-) 
*****NEW PERK!!*****

DVD available July 17!! Only 10 autographed copies available

The new work perk! This Bowl is hand carved, stamped, with inlaid slip. This one is painted with rabbit and flora.


*****NEW PERK*****
Thimble: for that precious something

Limited Edition Kline Pottery Tote Bag

Dinner plates for 4 or 6!

handprinted (and signed) thank you card!

Mug Up! or Mug+Tote perks!

pottery lesson perk for 1 or 2 persons + lunch 

luncheon/dessert plates in progress!

Let's fire perk includes 2 cubic feet of firing space

Stacey Lane limited edition earrings!

the rare pachyderm teapot. Limited numbered edition

Challenges

Building a new kiln requires a coordinated effort as most construction projects do, and William and I have put together a realistic timeline, yet the biggest challenge will be to learn the new kiln so that it becomes the tool I hope it will be. William's experience and expertise will ensure that the kiln fires properly and efficiently. With  each new kiln, there will be a learning curve. 

One last thing that I want to mention and it's an important one. I look forward to including you in the journey and will be in touch with frequent updates on the campaign and the projects. It's critical to the success of the campaign and in turn, the  completion of the kiln, that everyone help get the word out. 

Please share your participation with your fellow pottery loving friends, your coworkers, and all of your social media networks online. This helps in an exponential way to get the word out! You can do this by sharing this page on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, wherever you can! You can also share updates that I will make in the coming weeks! 

I look forward to firing many beautiful pots in this new kiln for years to come. Thank you in advance!!

The wood kiln I built in 2002 has served me well, and will still be fired several times a year. I have been working with master kiln builder, William Baker, to design the new propane fired soda kiln. The kiln will be smaller in scale than my wood kiln, and will be less labor intensive to fire. The smaller size will allow for a shorter turnaround as I experiment with surfaces and glazes. The new pots are time and labor intensive to make, so the scale of the kiln is important. I hired William for his design expertise as well as his meticulous attention to detail and skill as a builder. I will work alongside him to build the kiln, and I couldn't be more excited.


The soda kiln is the next great step for me as an artist. It will allow me to continue the momentum I have been building with this new body of work, and take it in new directions. Building a new kiln is a huge undertaking in every sense, and I thank you for helping me to achieve this dream.


   What We Need Building the kiln will require an upfront investment of $21,000
What's been done:

Kiln Shelves have been purchased
A kiln shed is built  
A concrete slab is ready to be poured
What's still needed :
Propane tank install
Gas lines trenched, installed, and connected
Purchase and shipment of super duty high temperature refractories
Steel work, including welding kiln bracing, chimney, damper, lentil, burner stands


4 B5 burners with 90 head 2.1 mil/BTU High Pressure LP

Concrete block and other  construction materials

What You Get
Along with the community of passionate supporters that you will be part of there are a few very nice perks for your generosity! Words can't always express my appreciation but sometimes pottery can! See descriptions for details. There are various times that I will be able to fulfill them, so please make a note of delivery schedules if you are thinking of sending some of these as gifts. Christmas is just around the corner! ;-) 

*****NEW PERK!!*****



DVD available July 17!! Only 10 autographed copies available




The new work perk! This Bowl is hand carved, stamped, with inlaid slip. This one is painted with rabbit and flora.

*****NEW PERK*****Thimble: for that precious something

Limited Edition Kline Pottery Tote Bag

Dinner plates for 4 or 6!


handprinted (and signed) thank you card!




Mug Up! or Mug+Tote perks!




pottery lesson perk for 1 or 2 persons + lunch 


luncheon/dessert plates in progress!


Let's fire perk includes 2 cubic feet of firing space


Stacey Lane limited edition earrings!




the rare pachyderm teapot. Limited numbered edition
Challenges
Building a new kiln requires a coordinated effort as most construction projects do, and William and I have put together a realistic timeline, yet the biggest challenge will be to learn the new kiln so that it becomes the tool I hope it will be. William's experience and expertise will ensure that the kiln fires properly and efficiently. With  each new kiln, there will be a learning curve. 
One last thing that I want to mention and it's an important one. I look forward to including you in the journey and will be in touch with frequent updates on the campaign and the projects. It's critical to the success of the campaign and in turn, the  completion of the kiln, that everyone help get the word out. 
Please share your participation with your fellow pottery loving friends, your coworkers, and all of your social media networks online. This helps in an exponential way to get the word out! You can do this by sharing this page on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, wherever you can! You can also share updates that I will make in the coming weeks! 
I look forward to firing many beautiful pots in this new kiln for years to come. Thank you in advance!!

story:
Hello world!! I’m Maraya Lopez, a.k.a. Lucas Berd. Originally, from Lubbock, Texas, I now reside and make art in Brooklyn,New York. I’m asking for your help funding my latest project, The Coney Island Magic Machine, the location where I will be an artist-in-residence, this summer (July). The Magic Machine will serve as my laboratory for research, reflection and exploration into new ideas for a new body of art work that I will later exhibit, after the residency is over. All the while, the project will give a voice to those who often times go unheard during moments of social and economic change.

Why now? 

The amusement area at Coney Island has been in flux for over 11 years now, with big development companies creeping in, changing the area dramatically. While change is good, one question constantly weighs on my mind. If and when Coney Island becomes homogenized through big money and corporate businesses, what will happen to those who live and work in Coney Island and where will they go to escape the daily grind. As it is, Coney Island is considered a low- income sector of New York, with a majority of it’s population living in 18 - 24 tower buildings, which are mostly forms of public housing. This artist residency cannot wait another year because there is a high chance that there will be high rises and a mall in the place of the Magic Machine. As places like Coney Island are becoming more and more obsolete, we must fight to keep them unique and affordable for all to enjoy, where everyone still has a place to feel free and creative. 

What will I actually be doing during the residency?

While is resident I will be working hard, researching, talking with locals and tourists alike, gaining a better understanding of their thoughts on the change at the park and their community. I will also be experimenting on a daily basis with materials, such as, vintage film and photography, documenting my experience and interactions during the residency. This is by no means a vacation, as I will continue to work my full-time job at the museum, Friday through Monday. Once the residency is over, I will transform my ideas and experience into a unique exhibition, to share with everyone I met, before the year is over. 

Coney Island has been a fundamental source of inspiration in my art work, since 2009.My personal fixation comes from the mysterious aura, nostalgia and weirdness that places like Coney Island emanate. My favorite time to visit is in the winter, when the park is empty and silent. The sky is usually a grayish blue color. It is reminiscent of growing up on the silent plains of Texas.  Coney Island is one of the last places on earth that embraces and accepts the minority for who they are. It is and always has been a creative and fundamental outlet for people of all social classes, cultures, genders, and races. Although, Coney Island has endured much change throughout it's history, including, Hurricane Sandy, it looks as if big money will someday soon, modify it for the worse. 

I am excited to share this project with you and am asking for your support through funding. My goal of $1,800 will go towards the rent and insurance of the space. As well as, the cost of materials and professional documentation of the project. Take a look at the many handmade and unique gifts on my perk’s page for a glimpse into the iconic Magic Machine.  Every little bit helps.

Your support not only helps me to create new body of work for an exhibition, it also sheds light on the people who live and work in Coney Island, who often times go unnoticed under the lights and sounds. Your donation will give a voice to people who otherwise may feel repressed. Please pass this along to friends who are Coney Island lovers or like to support the arts. INDIEGOGO makes sharing easy with their sharing tools!

Thanks for looking and your support!!!!!!!!!!!!

Maraya Lopez a.k.a. Lucas Berd

www.berdscarnival.com

Breakdown of funds:

Rent of Magic Machine (one month) 1,000.00

Insurance and fees: 100.00

Assistants/documentation of project: 475.00

Materials, art supplies and transportation: 225.00

Total: $1800.00

story:
The Project

Hello everyone! We are the Light Field group, a student team of the Virginia Tech chapter of Design for America. We've been working to foster a culture of public art and exploration at Virginia Tech through a highly visible and interactive installation. We hope that this will showcase the amalgam of technology and art, and also serve as a gathering place for people from both the local and regional area. 

The installation itself will be an array of balloons, each individually illuminated with LEDs. When unengaged, the field will remain statically illuminated. However, once a user enters the field, the balloons will become activated and change in color. Throughout the area will be several motion sensors which will be used to detect a user’s presence and trigger a shift in the balloon’s color. To further engage the community, the complex mechanics behind this project as well as the process have been documented from its conception. There will be a booth nearby to show this process and the mechanism.This project seeks to engage the community not only visually, but also experientially and educationally.


Why It's Important

This installation is important to bring the conversation of public art to a wider audience. We also hope a public showcasing of work will give rise to more opportunities for transdisciplinary cooperation and research by inspiring community members. In addition, there is the potential that the field could be repurposed and used as an educational tool to teach people about the nature of fields and how energy and information travel through waves.


How You Can Help

Any contributions that you are generous enough to send our way will be put towards purchasing the supplies needed to finish prototyping and create the final installation. This will include things such as arduinos, LEDs, balloons, and the other tools to make our installation a reality. We have a location (Henderson Lawn * in Blacksburg, Virginia) ready for May 4th- so we appreciate any support in being ready by that deadline! 
(PayPal is preferred, though we do take credit cards)

Any contributors will receive a lovely thank you note, as well as the knowledge that you helped spread arts and technology through a fantastic community!

We understand that many people can not contribute financially- and that's okay! We'd appreciate if you took the time to help us spread the word, through email, word of mouth, social media, or whatever else you deem appropriate. 

And that's all there is to it! Thank you all for taking the time to learn about our plans and goals. 

Make it a great day! 

-Habeeb, Callie, Anna, Lan, and Anna; Light Field at Virginia Tech


PROJECT UPDATE: Our location has changed to the Moss Center for the Arts Lawn! The date has remained the same. Still hope to see you all there! :)

story:
Short Summary

Four years ago I built the first drawing station, the "Naturalization Office" at Center Camp http://yuditskaya.com/interactive/wordpress/?page_id=88 
re-birth certificates are artworks and documents affirming world citizenry, global solidarity, and the personal right to freedom and choice:

This year the plan is to bring out a structure that has a camera-obscura based drawing station within it. It will combine the magic of optics and drawing from observation, to allow participants to make lasting memories and explore drawing from the right side of the brain.

We have the base structure but need funds for drafting supplies, and fabric to create the outer core of the Observer. 

What We Need & What You Get

We Need

  • Shade material
  • Inside/Outside Lighting
  • Drafting Supplies
  • Camera Lucida Supplies

You get

  • Custom made mystic pyramid stickers to color in with your friends and family
  • Instructions on assembling your own camera obscuras and lucidas
  • Art made just for you
The Impact

We literally do not have the funds to shade the structure, this contribution will provide for fabric that will:

  • Keep participants cool in the scorching heat of the Black Rock Desert
  • Shade the optics allowing for the camera obscura images to be visible
  • Provide shelter for participants in the event of a dust storm

We are also buying all the lighting out of the contributions from this campaign. Proper lighting will allow us to:

  • Better illuminate the sculpture at night to avoid bike accidents and people walking into the structure and banging themselves on it
  • Better illuminate the structure from the inside allowing participants to use the piece at night

Risks & Challenges

Burning man has provided tickets and early passes for the team, and Disorient has provided the wood and connectors to build the structure. But we are doing everything else out of pocket. This is why we need your help.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign far and wide. Every little bit counts for a lot ▲

story:
A Snapshot

My name is Naz and I am first and foremost an artist and happiest when capturing deep emotion on paper with my paintbrush. 

I am also in Stage 4 of cancer and advancing. As hope starts to fade, I have managed to re-kindle my love for art and free my thoughts onto paper, so that my mind can have a rest from them!

This campaign is all about enabling me to share with you my art as well as helping to fund my healing process. By contributing to this campaign, you will be making it possible for:

  • A test magazine run of my Illustrated Art Book featuring 16 of my original artworks created during the past year 
  • The publication of the actual hard cover book by the end of the year/beginning of 2016
  • The purchase of medical treatment required to slow the advancement of the cancer and ease the constant pain
  • My art to reach a multitude more people than I could imagine


So what is in this Book?

The illustrated art book contains 16 original artworks I made by hand using mixed media. Some of the pages of the book simply capture a deep emotion I either experienced or dreamt of whilst in hospice for pain control over the three months earlier this year. Here I learned to stop and look at the flowers, seeing people like me with cancer come and go, sometimes gone forever... 

I completed the rest of the artworks recently as art continued to be a form of colour and being for me, and a meditative way to scrabble through the cloud of grey that always seems to follow me above my head. 

Learning how to cope is the key, and I have found that nothing heals the body like the language of heart emotion. No pill can cure deeper than this wave of love activated by our deep wanting of change, a way of looking forward to something greater. Happiness of the heart and not being afraid to dream is my emotion I try to portray throughout this book. 

I hope you are able to get your hands on a copy and pray you will be impacted as you immerse yourself in the magical pages of illustrations and words in this crazy journey me and so many others are going through. 


What We Need

FIRST PHASE: Magazine Test run

I need £600 in this initial campaign in order to print the short run of the books. This will allow me to sell the books to family and friends (and friends of friends hopefully!) at £10.

SECOND PHASE: Book Publication

With the funds from the books sold, I should be able to have my book published with its own ISBN and sold at £20, with the aim of selling to the general public and earning more funds.

ONGOING PHASE: Healing

With the funds from the sale of the above phases, I hope to be able to purchase some (very expensive) medical treatment as an alternative to the current chemotherapy I am receiving, which does not appear to be healing me. 


The Impact

By donating to this campaign, you are enabling me to leave the legacy I dream of in this world. While my life may be cut short from me, I want to help and share with as many people as I can (cancer sufferers, family, friends and anyone else who has been touched by it) the true emotional roller coaster that a cancer sufferer goes through and the message that we should not take for granted the beauty of life.


Risks & Challenges

I'm still strong and have been working on this project with all my heart when I have the strength. However, it is challenging, especially on the days where reality hits and I am in so much pain, bones are breaking and it is impossible to sleep. This is real life but it will not stop me from bringing to the world these illustrations and words to impact the lives of others. 

I have a few people helping me make this art book vision come to life. The hope is that we can achieve this before it is too late, but we need your help financially to keep the dream alive. 


Other Ways You Can Help

I understand if you're not in the position to contribute financially at this time. However, if you have friends and family who you know would be interested in supporting, please share this campaign on your social media (Facebook, Twitter etc), email or in person word of mouth, and I will be eternally grateful!


Final Thoughts

Going through cancer can be like any other struggle in life that stops you from moving forward. Emotionally the struggle can become unbearable, the chain and ball of cancer are heavy, as is the loss of others from  cancer can be devastating too. Even in the deepest pit, there can be hope of achieving our goals, as it is only in the lowest time of our lives that wake us up and urge us to choose between living a better way or giving up entirely.

While I feel lost and alone and want to let go and be free of all of this, I know that even on my off days, the greater picture is there and there is hope.

Thanks for supporting me in this journey and dream.

story:
Our Story:

This year, Movement Research will finally have a long-term home! We’ll be moving into three gorgeous spaces at the 122 Community Center (122CC). Housed in the former Public School 122 at the corner of First Avenue and Ninth Street, 122CC is also the home to The Alliance for Positive Change, Mabou Mines, Painting Space 122 and Performance Space New York. This move is a historic moment for our performing arts community, and one that will benefit all of the communities that MR serves – throughout New York City, across the country and around the world.

 

The new space at 122CC will offer:

  • A fully ADA accessible space, including accessible studios and restrooms
  • Increased interaction between MR’s programs, as well as with the surrounding communities in the building and in the neighborhood
  • Expansion of MR’s programs to meet the needs of our growing artist communities
  • Unprecedented organizational stability through shelter from rising rents
  • More subsidized rehearsal space!

In order to make this historic move, MR needs the effort of every member of our community. Together, we will ensure that MR will remain a leading laboratory for the investigation of dance and movement-based forms in the decades to come.

 

What We Need

Your support for this campaign will fund the critical first phase of the move: installation of sprung dance floors and the move into the new space! MR has received support from the Howard Gilman Foundation and Mertz Gilmore Foundation, as well as several initial seed donors. Together, we can raise the remaining $20,000 needed to complete this first essential phase of the move.

 

What You Can Get

To celebrate your generosity at this critical moment in MR’s history, we’ll invite all contributors of $10 or more to write on the donor wall in our new office. Pick up a sharpie and make your mark on the MOST D.I.Y. DONOR WALL EVER! Altogether now!

These perks are available with your generous donation of $25 or more: 

  • Donors who give $25 will be able to pick up a one class card.
  • Donors who give $50 will be able to pick up a pair of black Movement Research crew socks. YES. They are black, and emblazoned with the white MR logo.
  • Donors who give $100 will be able to pick up a stainless steel MR water bottle.
  • Donors who give $250 will be able to pick up an MR umbrella, black with our bright white logo, PLUS your choice of crew socks or water bottle.
  • Donors who give $500 and more can pick up all three – socks, water bottle, AND umbrella.

Have too much STUFF in your life? No worries! You can easily give without receiving any goodies. You'll still get to sign our wall!

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to direct contributions to Movement Research’s Capital Campaign, please also consider other ways to support our move:

Spread the word!

Share this campaign with family, friends, friends-of-friends, even felines! Follow us on Facebook and Instagram. Repost and use our hashtags – #MRmoveshome #buildthatfloor. Our greatest asset is our community – that's you!

Offer your time!

Please email volunteer@movementresearch.org with specific inquiries.

Become a Friend!

If you can’t give right now, that’s ok! Our Friends of Movement Research Program engages individuals towards a collective giving effort and in return, offers benefits year-round. The generous support from our Friends is critical to Movement Research’s long-term sustainability and success – we couldn’t do it without you!
story_txt:
Our Story:
This year, Movement Research will finally have a long-term home! We’ll be moving into three gorgeous spaces at the 122 Community Center (122CC). Housed in the former Public School 122 at the corner of First Avenue and Ninth Street, 122CC is also the home to The Alliance for Positive Change, Mabou Mines, Painting Space 122 and Performance Space New York. This move is a historic moment for our performing arts community, and one that will benefit all of the communities that MR serves – throughout New York City, across the country and around the world. The new space at 122CC will offer:

A fully ADA accessible space, including accessible studios and restrooms
Increased interaction between MR’s programs, as well as with the surrounding communities in the building and in the neighborhood
Expansion of MR’s programs to meet the needs of our growing artist communities
Unprecedented organizational stability through shelter from rising rents
More subsidized rehearsal space!

In order to make this historic move, MR needs the effort of every member of our community. Together, we will ensure that MR will remain a leading laboratory for the investigation of dance and movement-based forms in the decades to come. What We Need
Your support for this campaign will fund the critical first phase of the move: installation of sprung dance floors and the move into the new space! MR has received support from the Howard Gilman Foundation and Mertz Gilmore Foundation, as well as several initial seed donors. Together, we can raise the remaining $20,000 needed to complete this first essential phase of the move.
 
What You Can Get
To celebrate your generosity at this critical moment in MR’s history, we’ll invite all contributors of $10 or more to write on the donor wall in our new office. Pick up a sharpie and make your mark on the MOST D.I.Y. DONOR WALL EVER! Altogether now!
These perks are available with your generous donation of $25 or more: 

Donors who give $25 will be able to pick up a one class card.
Donors who give $50 will be able to pick up a pair of black Movement Research crew socks. YES. They are black, and emblazoned with the white MR logo.
Donors who give $100 will be able to pick up a stainless steel MR water bottle.
Donors who give $250 will be able to pick up an MR umbrella, black with our bright white logo, PLUS your choice of crew socks or water bottle.
Donors who give $500 and more can pick up all three – socks, water bottle, AND umbrella.

Have too much STUFF in your life? No worries! You can easily give without receiving any goodies. You'll still get to sign our wall!
Other Ways You Can Help
In addition to direct contributions to Movement Research’s Capital Campaign, please also consider other ways to support our move:
Spread the word!
Share this campaign with family, friends, friends-of-friends, even felines! Follow us on Facebook and Instagram. Repost and use our hashtags – #MRmoveshome #buildthatfloor. Our greatest asset is our community – that's you!
Offer your time!
Please email volunteer@movementresearch.org with specific inquiries.
Become a Friend!
If you can’t give right now, that’s ok! Our Friends of Movement Research Program engages individuals towards a collective giving effort and in return, offers benefits year-round. The generous support from our Friends is critical to Movement Research’s long-term sustainability and success – we couldn’t do it without you!

story:
“Let us put our minds together to see what life we can make for our children.”  ~ Sitting Bull

Singing Tall Grass believes in the need to promote more community gardens and beehives, for land, great cultures and communities to thrive!


Our mission is to raise money with this beautiful painting, "The Chief". The "Chief" painting is to be auctioned, and the proceeds will go to funding the development and progress for a community garden project and building bee hives. 

Mikarla Teague custom painted this painting for Singing Tall Grass's "Featured Artists Series". Singing Tall Grass owns a line of organic beauty products that features art from collaborating artists that support developing community gardens. This painting too, will also be on labels on "Singing Tall Grass" organic beauty  products in an effort to further raise awareness for OLCERI and other great organizations that benefit organic living and farming/gardening. With this unique way of raising awareness, it can be a mobile advertisment on a chap stick tube, instead of only being admired on a wall!

We chose to start with OLCERI, short for "Oglala Lakota Cultural & Economic Revitalization Initiative." We our raising awareness and money for Oglala Lakota Cultural & Economic Revitalization Initiative. Their mission is to create and facilitate the conditions for resilience, self-sufficiency, economic independence and cultural revitalization amongst the Lakota at Pine Ridge reservation in South Dakota. You can visit their site at www.olceri.org.

OLCERI's programs and projects, serve to promote, teach and establish long-term food security for the Olgala Lakota community of Pine Ridge.

They have great community building programs in place, and are looking to expand more. Here are their programs:


Existing programs include:

Gardening • Wind power • Straw bale building • Nature awareness

Cattle ranch • Mustang rescue program

Planned for 2011/2012:

Mobile library • Community supported agriculture • Natural building • Tree planting

Water catchment and conservation • Food forest • Buffalo • Wind towers

Hi-efficiency stove production • Cooperative business and job opportunities.


Thank you for helping to make a difference!

story:
Q: WHAT HAPPENS WHEN ARTISTS GET TO PLAY WITH THE 150,000 TONS OF SALT NOT USED TO MELT SNOW IN NYC THIS WINTER?

A: LUMEN 2012!

INTERNATIONAL VIDEO AND PERFORMANCE FESTIVAL

SATURDAY, JUNE 23, 6PM – MIDNIGHT (ONE NIGHT ONLY)

ATLANTIC SALT Co. FACILITY, STATEN ISLAND, NY

www.lumenfest.org           

 
Presented by the Council On the Arts & Humanities for Staten Island (COAHSI). Christopher Eamon, Artistic Director
 
Free and open to the public.
 
A 15 Minute Walk from SI Ferry + Free Bus Shuttle. Bicycle Valet courtesy Transportation Alternatives.

What We Need & What You Get

COAHSI helps artists subsidize their installation needs. We need to raise approximately $2500 to help cover these costs. Raised funds will help cover permit fees, equipment rentals and help pay our artists and curators.

In turn you will receive cool perks and original artist work by LUMEN artists including:

  • Brendan Coyle
  • Ola Ignesiak & Andrzej Sieczkowski
  • Victoria Gibson
  • Jason Irla
  • Steven Lapcevic
  • Philip David Stearns, and
  • Edmund Varuolo

and...

YOU WILL GET TO BEAR WITNESS and BOAST SUPPORT of 50 + Artists who will transform mountains of gleaming white salt, derelict historic buildings, and the industrial waterfront of Staten Island into a surreal and spectacular luminous playground.

 

The Impact

Your contribution supports cutting-edge, contemporary, new media art installation on Staten Island.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute dollars, that doesn’t you can’t help:

  • Help spread the word and make some noise about LUMEN. Use the Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign on all sorts of social media interfaces!
  • Have audio or visual equipment that you would be willing to lend to an artist for the night? Want to help set up, during the event, or with the break down? Please contact Monica Valenzuela at mvalenzuela@statenislandarts.org or 718-447-3329 x 1004 to see how you can help.

 

PERKS!!!

For $10 YOUR NAME IS ON LUMEN'S WEBSITE:

 

For $25, we write you a thank you note AND your name is on the LUMEN website!

 

For $75, you get all of the above... AND a vintage LUMEN LOVER PIN!

 

For $150... one of the following original prints by LUMEN artists could be yours!

Artist Print - Steven Lapcevic, STATION I, 2012. Courtesy of Artist.

Artist Print - Steven Lapcevic, STATION II, 2012. Courtesy of Artist.

Artist Print - Jeanne Verdoux, Limited edition monoprint (1/1) ONLY ONE!!!

Artist Print - Phillip David Stearns, Untitled 1. Courtesy of Artist.

Artist Print - Phillip David Stearns, Untitled 2. Courtesy of Artist.

Artist Print - Victoria Gibson. Courtesy of Artist.

Artist Print - Ed Varuolo, Zombie Walk. Courtesy of Artist.

 

For $300 you can choose two of the above artist prints or have LUMEN artist Brendan Coyle design a 4" tattoo for you!

 

For $700 you will receive the following digital print (45x60 in) on PVC, by LUMEN artist Jason Irla --- shipped directly to your home or office!

Jason Irla, The Ocean Stays Focused, 2012. Courtesy of Artist.

 

YOUR $2000 pledge grants you:

EITHER...

A custom, original, permanant Colorful Puddle by LUMEN artists Ola Ignasiak & Andrzej (dyed resin with natural pigment). 

OR

A custom motion graphics video for you or your place of business by LUMEN artist collaborative VolVox.

story:
WHO'S DOING THIS AND WHY

I'm Josh di Donato. I'm a standup comedian, but I have a bachelor's degree in Fine Art from UCLA.

I've been taking Polaroids at the Coachella Festival since 2001, and have over 1800 Polaroids from this festival 2001-2011. I'm looking to do a book of the best pictures. There will probably be 200-250 pictures, about 20 from each year. If the book is a success, I certainly have enough shots to do a second volume.

I am dedicated to keeping the Instant Photography flag flying. Digital photography is nice, because most everyone now has the ability to take pictures. But a by-product of thousands of images being generated without much effort or thought or stakes, means that the individual image has lost its significance. Polaroids make each picture something that can be treasured.

I haven't found a publisher for this book yet, though I haven't stopped looking. The options in self-publishing are such that I can make a first printing of the book myself, with the hope that a publishing company would pick it up for a second printing.

HOW IT'S ALL GOING TO HAPPEN

There are two niche demographics I can target this book toward- fans of Polaroids, and fans of the Coachella Festival. There are many people who are devoted to both these things.

From what I can tell, it would take $20,000 to print 1,000 books, and have them look really good. Over the past ten-plus years, I have spent over $20,000 on cameras and film- mostly on the film. This film is not cheap.

Having already invested so much of my own money over the last decade, it's going to be challenging to additionally fund the printing. This is why I have posted this project here. I believe I have the makings of what could be a successful book. Not a runaway bestseller or anything, but something that more than 1000 people would like to have on their coffee table!

There are different Polaroid enthusiast websites, including The Impossible Project, who are the people who put out the new film made for Polaroid cameras, since the Polaroid company discontinued making the standard 600, 1200 and SX-70 film. I can connect with other Polaroid fans through TIP, Flickr, and other sites where Polaroidists post their work.

There are also many gathering places for fans of Coachella, and chances to connect and get the word out via the Coachella website message boards, Facebook page, etc.

SEE A PREVIEW OF WHAT WILL BE IN THE BOOK

There are some examples in my pitch video here on IndieGoGo. You can see more of the Polaroids at Facebook.com/CoachellaPolaroids . As of this writing, most of them are up. When I get back from the festival this weekend, this will be modified, and there will be fewer that are viewable.

SOME PERKS

For some levels of donation, you can get a mention in the Thanks section of the book when it comes out, have a signed copy of the book, have one of my Polaroid cameras from my personal collection (I have quite a few), get a pack of some of the last original Polaroid film, or have me do a Polaroid shoot of you and your friends, in LA, or anywhere in the US!

TELL PEOPLE

If you can't donate, but know people who would be interested in this project, please post about it on Facebook, Tumblr, Twitter, or any other place you think would reach interested parties.

 

Thanks,

Josh  di Donato

story:
Hello and Welcome!

We are Jane, Lisa, and Jeremy from the Victory Gallery in Portland, Oregon. We are dedicated tobringing new and exciting work to our city. Though our area is very art-conscious, we are dedicated to pushing the boundaries and testing the limits. We are dedicated to standing out. We are dedicated tobringing the public free artwork from around the world.We are dedicated.But we need your financial help to continue to bring cutting-edge art to our fair city. Our worthy cause canuse whatever funds you can spare – your donation of even the two dollars you spend on coffee in themorning will help.

Here is what we need:

Our goal is to raise $7,000 right now to cover our basic costs for a three month period, which roughly
translates to this:

Shipping of artwork: $1,500

Travel costs for artists to do Q and A's and give lectures : $2,000

Hanging art and cleaning of the gallery: $400

General costs for opening, closing, seating, refreshments, and lighting: $500

General gallery maintenance and upkeep: $600

Payment for design and printing of all publicity material: $1,800

What do you get in return? So MUCH! We have buttons, posters, postcards, stickers, donor certificates,
private viewings prior to a show’s opening, books, booklets, T-shirts, and much, much more.

Why this is important to you.

Your contribution will not only help us survive, it will help us continue to grow and expand. More than anything, the gallery is meant as a place for both first time viewers and long-time art critics to mingle and share opinions. Our approach will educate, entertain, and inspire you while providing free access to innovative and thought  provoking artists with a global perspective.

Don't have money? Don't worry!

You're broke. We get it. That's totally fine. Everyone is having a hard time right now. But if you could share this with your friends, family, relatives, work buddies, band members, gallery friends, sugar  daddies, wealthy second uncles, Bill Gates, or anyone else you might know, we would greatly appreciate
it.

Thank you for your support!

Victory Gallery

story:
About 'More Than Just A Machete'

From a vengeful mother to a deranged hillbilly, copycat killer to possessed bystander, the surprisingly varied cast of villains throughout our favorite horror franchise have brandished an equally diverse set of killing tools. Collecting every single handheld weapon utilized for dissecting the many victims of summer camp, Manhattan, and outer space, this unique design creates a bold image reflecting the simple-yet-complex nature of these classic slasher films. Plus, it totally looks kick-ass!

About Darb Tees

Darb Tees is a T-shirt company and website featuring humorous designs that merge original ideas with established pop culture staples. Shirts are produced in a limited quantity since we believe people aren't just buying a shirt, they're investing in a limited edition piece of wearable art. Shirts are 100% cotton and guaranteed to make an impression - but hurry, as once a shirt has sold out it'll be gone forever!

Why Should You Donate?

For several years, Darb Tees has been a dream that we've poured all of our creative thoughts into in the hopes of one day bringing this vision to reality. All money raised through this campaign will be utilized to purchase shirts, have them imprinted with our design, and finally made available for purchase through our website, DarbTees.com. As young entrepreneurs, we hope for Darb Tees to be the first step towards fulfilling all of our creative aspirations - and we'd like for you to be a part of it. Your donation, no matter how big or small, will not only help independent artists but provide you with exciting perks including shout-outs, original T-shirts, and artwork.

Sharing Our Fundraiser

Please, help us share Darb Tees with the world! Whether you repost our website, follow us on Twitter, like us on Facebook, or just want to send us a positive message (DarbTees@gmail.com), we appreciate any support you can provide. Thank you so much, and happy Friday the 13th!

story:
An Artists Story

As an artist, based in Grand Rapids, Michigan, I believe in creating opportunities for others to discover and nurture their artistic and creative abilities. 

Salon 477 is a network of Grand Rapids artists used to mentor, support and provide opportunities for emerging artists to display and sell their work.

The Artists residency trip to Israel will provide the opportunity for me to journey alongside Israeli and Palestinian artists exploring what it means to create within the context of our varying cultures. It will consist of two weeks of intensive work through workshops, lectures and art creation. It is also about learning by visiting the Christian, Jewish, and Muslim holy sites, and meeting Israelis and Palestinians working on peace and reconciliation. The goal is to learn to integrate faith and justice into our art, to approach our body of work as a legacy that will communicate responsibly who we were and the times we lived.

The Impact

As a result of this trip I aim to:

  • strengthen my voice as an artist within my community and learn to effectively utilize my work as a communication tool that will leave a lasting impact
  • inspire and encourage my students to have a broader view of the world around them
  • facilitate conversations among artists in my community about our work and how we use it.
  • gain a deeper understanding about the power behind artistic expression and what art can mean for those who need a voice.

What I Need

I need to raise $4000 for airfare, transit, field costs and personal expenses.

Airfare and transit: $1400, Field costs: $2000 (room, breakfast and dinner, entrance to sites, gratuities, honorariums to all of the speakers, cost of my insurance), $600:lunch and personal expenses (entertainment, souvenirs, toiletries) 

What You Get

By becoming a part of this life changing experience, your involvement will:

  • support my artistic development and encourage art for social change
  • secure your invitation to a special viewing of a new body of work this fall (for funders living in Grand Rapids and surrounding areas).

 

Money isn't the only thing that matters...

Helping me spread the word and sharing this with your friends and family on Facebook is invaluable. I appreciate your help in any way possible.

Thank you for being a part of my story.

 

Georgia Taylor, Salon 477

The Artists residency trip to Israel will provide the opportunity for me to journey alongside Israeli and Palestinian artists exploring what it means to create within the context of our varying cultures. It will consist of two weeks of intensive work through workshops, lectures and art creation. It is also about learning by visiting the Christian, Jewish, and Muslim holy sites, and meeting Israelis and Palestinians working on peace and reconciliation. The goal is to learn to integrate faith and justice into our art, to approach our body of work as a legacy that will communicate responsibly who we were and the times we lived.
The Impact
As a result of this trip I aim to:

strengthen my voice as an artist within my community and learn to effectively utilize my work as a communication tool that will leave a lasting impact
inspire and encourage my students to have a broader view of the world around them
facilitate conversations among artists in my community about our work and how we use it.
gain a deeper understanding about the power behind artistic expression and what art can mean for those who need a voice.


What I Need
I need to raise $4000 for airfare, transit, field costs and personal expenses.
Airfare and transit: $1400, Field costs: $2000 (room, breakfast and dinner, entrance to sites, gratuities, honorariums to all of the speakers, cost of my insurance), $600:lunch and personal expenses (entertainment, souvenirs, toiletries) 
What You Get
By becoming a part of this life changing experience, your involvement will:

support my artistic development and encourage art for social change
secure your invitation to a special viewing of a new body of work this fall (for funders living in Grand Rapids and surrounding areas).

 


Money isn't the only thing that matters...
Helping me spread the word and sharing this with your friends and family on Facebook is invaluable. I appreciate your help in any way possible.
Thank you for being a part of my story.
 
Georgia Taylor, Salon 477

story:
Our Story

We are Unknown Concepts and Unknown Choppers. We manufacture choppers and chopper frames hand-made right here in the USA. We are raising funds to start production of our Frantom-R concept. 



The Impact

The Frantom-R is an enclosed trike with full roll cage that protects the rider, has air-ride suspension, rear view video camera, touch screen radio and navigation and many more features. 


 


What We Need

All money raised will be used to further the production of the Frantom-R concept. The bulk of the money will be spent on material cost like:


-Metal: Tubing for chassis, metal to build a chassis JIG to hold the chassis during fabrication

-140" V-Twin Motor

-6 Speed Transmission with reverse

-Wheels and tires 

-Fiberglass and fiberglass equipment

-Custom glass

-Air ride suspension

-Electronics


What You Get

11"x17" Exclusive poster for Indiegogo Funders


Exclusive "I put the GOGO in this project" t-shirt!





18"x24" Exclusive Personalized poster with your name on the door for Indiegogo Funders!

1/8" 3D Printed model of the Frantom-R Exclusive to Indiegogo Funders! 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you like what you see, please feel free to share with your friends!

story:
NEW SCALE75 STEAMPUNK PROJECT

This is a new initiative from SCALE75 to raise funds for the development of a new STEAMPUNK style 75 mm scale-miniature.

Following our market launch of the STEAM WARS series and our first campaign on Indiegogo, we decided to attempt an even more complex and exciting new challenge, cenntred in the wonderful world of Steampunk in miniature.



We want to create an even more striking and complicated new miniature with many more accessories, to add to our series. Our main aim is to create one of the best concepts of the STEAM WARS series that we´ve designed so far. We need your help to enable us to surpass the eroticism; the elegance and the quality of our previous creations in this new project. 

Our new creation will delight the most demanding painters and collectors; one of our famous girls set within a detailed background with a spectacular exclusive steampunk designed motorbike. Sarah Kilmister, our biker, is ready to be modelled and brought to life and is prepared to form part of your collection!

The new scene is designed by the brilliant illustrator Adrian Prado, modelled by the remarkable sculptor Alfonso Prieto / Ivan Pardo and painted by two of the greatest artists in the miniature fantasy-world, Elías Alonso and Alfonso Giraldes (Banshee).

All this, linked to our brand’s unique style of production quality and detail, will make this new project irresistible.Help us achieve our goal, take advantage of all our packs before the official release, and be a part of this new project from SCALE75.

Help us develop our ideas and exciting projects, we’re counting on you!!!



- High Quality Steam Wars Poster Collection in PDF (30,7x51 cm). 


- Amelia Steam Figure with High Quality Poster in PDF (30,7x51 cm). 


- "Fix it" Sam Figure with High Quality Poster in PDF (30,7x51 cm). 


- Kitty Reimer Figure with High Quality Poster in PDF (30,7x51 cm). 


- Ilsa Mech Figure with High Quality Poster in PDF (30,7x51 cm). 


- Sarah Kilmister Figure with High Quality Poster in PDF (30,7x51 cm). 


- Amelia Steam, "Fix it" Sam, Kitty Reimer and Ilsa Mech Figures with High Quality Posters in PDF (30,7x51 cm). 


- Sarah Kilmister, Amelia Steam, "Fix it" Sam, Kitty Reimer and Ilsa Mech Figures with High Quality Posters in PDF (30,7x51 cm).


- Two miniatures to choose between Kitty Reimer, Amelia Steam and "Fix it" Sam Figures with High Quality Posters in PDF (30,7x51 cm).


- Sarah Kilmister and Amelia Steam, "Fix it" Sam or Kitty Reimer Figures with High Quality Posters in PDF (30,7x51 cm). 


- Sarah Kilmister and Ilsa Mech Figures with High Quality Posters in PDF (30,7x51 cm).


- Sarah Kilmister Figure with your own female face.


- One Scalecolor Paint Set to choose.


- One Scale75 Classic Figure to choose.


- Sarah Kilmister Figure with High Quality Poster in PDF (30,7x51 cm).


- Sarah Kilmister´s Motorbike with High Quality Poster in PDF (30,7x51 cm).


- Sarah Kilmister´s Scenery with High Quality Poster in PDF (30,7x51 cm).



SCALE75 is a Spanish company that is recognized worldwide in the creation, production and marketing of metal figures in miniature. Also SCALE75 has its own line of accessories and paints for all kinds of miniatures. 

In SCALE75's catalog you can enjoy the great characters, heroes, myths, legends, villains and warriors throughout history, created upon the most revolutionary artistic concepts of modeling. 

You can find fantasy miniature lines of different styles, created by the most amazing artists in the world. Character, movement, detail, strength, beauty and epic are the distinguishing features of all of our creations.

You can know more in depth in www.scale75.com

and through our Facebook page: 

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Scale-75/127998963919682?ref=hl

In this case our Campaign focuses on one of the new characters in our STEAMPUNK series. We hope you enjoy it as much as we will.

You can help us by sharing the campaign to all your contacts and selecting one of our Perks. By helping us you will get greatly reduced prices before the release of the figures.
